nodes.text: The impact of retirement savings policies on total wealth accumulation depends on whether they change behavior through active choice (price subsidies) or passive choice (automatic contributions)

Data: administrative panel of Denmark covering 41 million person-year observations (1995-2009) with third-party reports of pension flows and taxable-asset balances; institutional detail on capital vs annuity pensions, employer contributions, and 1998 MSP and 1999 subsidy reform

Two-type conceptual model: active savers optimize intertemporally and respond to price subsidies; passive savers set fixed pension contributions and are influenced by automatic contributions; model predicts diﬀerent comparative statics for automatic contributions vs subsidies

Empirical designs: employer-switch event studies and panel regressions to identify employer pension pass-through; regression discontinuity (RD) at MSP cutoff to identify mandated contributions; difference-in-differences (DD) and triple-interaction IVs to identify subsidy impacts and crowd-out

Automatic contributions (employer or mandated) substantially raise total saving because most individuals do not offset them: employer-contribution increases pass through ~94% to total pension contributions and ~78% to total saving (holding total compensation fixed); estimated persistence over 10 years produces substantially higher retirement wealth

Mandated Savings Plan (MSP, 1998) RD result: eligibility jump of DKr 345 increases total pension contributions and total saving with pass-through estimates near or above 80%; threshold analyses imply high pass-through of mandated contributions to total saving
Price subsidy reform (1999): capital-pension tax deduction reduced for top-bracket taxpayers; individual capital pension contributions fell sharply among treated incomes

Only a minority actively respond to subsidy changes: distributional evidence and event comparisons imply about 19% of prior contributors actively reoptimized after the 1999 subsidy cut (most of them exiting capital pensions); 81% of prior contributors did not change contributions, implying passive behavior with respect to price subsidies

Mechanism: passive savers keep voluntary pension contributions and taxable saving unchanged when automatic contributions rise, so automatic contributions raise aggregate saving via reduced consumption or maintained taxable saving targets

Within-retirement-account substitution after subsidy cut: estimated that 57% of each DKr reduction in capital pensions shifted to annuity pensions (so total pension contributions fell by 43 cents per DKr)

Crowd-out to taxable saving: using MPS and threshold IV strategies, nearly all of the reduction in retirement contributions was offset by increases in taxable saving (best estimates near 99% crowd-out; trimmed and threshold-based estimates clustered near full offset), implying that each DKr of subsidy spending produced essentially zero net new saving (point estimate ≈ 0.01 DKr of new saving, 95% CI upper bound ≈ 0.28 DKr)

Estimated population composition: approximately 15% active savers who respond to price subsidies and tend to be wealthier, older, and more financially sophisticated; approximately 85% passive savers who are unresponsive to subsidies but respond to automatic contributions

Policy implication: automatic contributions (defaults, mandated or employer contributions) are more effective at increasing total savings among those least prepared for retirement and have higher fiscal eﬃcacy than tax-deferred subsidies which mainly induce asset shifts among a small, already-sophisticated subset
